Customer Churn Analysis
========================================================

# Abstract

This is an exploration of customer churn patterns in [Your Company/Industry]. For this exploratory data analysis, I am analyzing customer data from [Your Data Source]. The dataset contains customer information from [Start Date] to [End Date].

Throughout the analysis, I will attempt to answer the following questions:

1. What is the overall churn rate?
2. What are the key factors influencing customer churn?
3. Which customer segments are most likely to churn?
4. How does churn vary across different subscription plans/services?
5. What are the characteristics of customers who stay vs. those who leave?
6. Can we build a predictive model to identify at-risk customers?

Predictive Modeling

In this section, I'll build a predictive model to identify customers at risk of churning. I'll use logistic regression and evaluate its performance.

```{r echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
# Data preparation for modeling
library(caret)

# Select features and prepare data
model_data <- churn_data %>%
  select(tenure, MonthlyCharges, TotalCharges, Contract, 
         InternetService, PaymentMethod, OnlineSecurity, 
         TechSupport, PaperlessBilling, Churn)

# Convert to factors
model_data$Churn <- as.factor(model_data$Churn)
model_data$Churn <- relevel(model_data$Churn, ref = "Yes")

# Handle missing values
model_data <- na.omit(model_data)

# Create dummy variables
dummies <- dummyVars(Churn ~ ., data = model_data)
model_ready <- predict(dummies, newdata = model_data)
model_ready <- as.data.frame(model_ready)
model_ready$Churn <- model_data$Churn

# Split data
set.seed(123)
train_index <- createDataPartition(model_ready$Churn, p = 0.7, list = FALSE)
train_data <- model_ready[train_index, ]
test_data <- model_ready[-train_index, ]

# Train logistic regression model
logit_model <- glm(Churn ~ ., data = train_data, family = "binomial")
summary(logit_model)
```

Interpreting the Results of the Logistic Regression Model

Key findings from the model:

· Tenure: For each additional month of tenure, the odds of churning decrease by approximately X%
· Monthly Charges: Higher monthly charges increase churn probability
· Contract Type: Two-year contracts significantly reduce churn odds (p < 0.001)
· Online Security: Having online security reduces churn by approximately Y%
· Tech Support: Access to tech support reduces churn probability

Assessing the predictive Ability of the Model

```{r echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
# Make predictions
predictions <- predict(logit_model, newdata = test_data, type = "response")
predicted_class <- ifelse(predictions > 0.5, "Yes", "No")

# Create confusion matrix
conf_matrix <- confusionMatrix(as.factor(predicted_class), 
                               test_data$Churn, positive = "Yes")
conf_matrix

# ROC Curve
roc_curve <- roc(test_data$Churn, predictions)
auc_value <- auc(roc_curve)

# Plot ROC
plot(roc_curve, main = paste("ROC Curve (AUC =", round(auc_value, 3), ")"),
     col = "#A23B72", lwd = 2)
abline(a = 0, b = 1, lty = 2, col = "gray")

# Feature importance
importance <- varImp(logit_model)
importance_df <- data.frame(
  Feature = rownames(importance),
  Importance = importance$Overall
) %>%
  arrange(desc(Importance))

ggplot(aes(x = reorder(Feature, Importance), y = Importance), 
       data = head(importance_df, 15)) +
  geom_bar(stat = 'identity', fill = "#2E86AB") +
  coord_flip() +
  ggtitle('Top 15 Feature Importance for Churn Prediction') +
  xlab('Feature') +
  ylab('Importance') +
  theme_minimal()
```

The model achieves r round(conf_matrix$overall['Accuracy'] * 100, 1)% accuracy with an AUC of r round(auc_value, 3). Key predictors include contract type, tenure, and online security status.
